messages.title: Richest 1,000 Britons double wealth as poverty rises
messages.content: The richest thousand people in Britain have seen their wealth double in five years. Their combined wealth now adds up to £519 billion. At the same time, wages of ordinary people have fallen.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: A 2% wealth tax on the richest 1% of people in Britain, raising around £40 billion.
Increasing the minimum wage to £10 an hour.
Proper investment in the NHS, care homes, youth centres and all our vital public services.
A crackdown on the tax dodging of big businesses and the mega-rich.

mentions.candidate: Ann says: "I’ve worked as an economist all over the world, and one thing is absolutely clear: austerity doesn’t work. It isn’t working in the UK, unless you’re in the wealthiest 1%."

issues.economy: A 2% wealth tax on the richest 1%, minimum wage increase to £10 an hour.
issues.governance: A crackdown on the tax dodging of big businesses and the mega-rich.

housing.content: Proper investment in the NHS, care homes, youth centres and all our vital public services.

leaflet.personalStatement: "I’m standing to be MP for Oxford East because I’ve seen how this dogma has eroded our public services and turned our city into the most unaffordable place to live in the UK. It’s time to do something about that."

politicalExperience.achievements: Worked as an economist all over the world. Work in South Asia, Africa, and America as well as the UK. Family was exiled for fighting against apartheid.

quotes.text: "We don’t need to destroy our public services - we just need to build a fairer economy."
"I’ve worked as an economist all over the world, and one thing is absolutely clear: austerity doesn’t work. It isn’t working in the UK, unless you’re in the wealthiest 1%."

"I’m standing to be MP for Oxford East because I’ve seen how this dogma has eroded our public services and turned our city into the most unaffordable place to live in the UK. It’s time to do something about that."

leaflet.additionalNotes: Ann Duncan is a former World Bank economist with experience working in multiple regions including South Asia, Africa, and America. Her family fought against apartheid.
